bibl.title: Chin Quock Wah vs. Henry M. White. Criminal.
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the microfilmed original.

org.orgName: Western District Court of Washington, Northern Division

div1.p: IN THE UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT, IN AND FOR THE WESTERN DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON, NORTHERN DIVISION.
In the Matter of the Application of CHIN QUOCK WAH, for a Writ of Habeas Corpus. ) No 2971 MEMORANDUM BRIEF.

This was an application by Chin Quock Wah, through his attorneys, Beeler & Sullivan, for a Writ of Habeas Corpus, asking that he be discharged,on the grounds that he was illegally detained by the Commissioner of Immigration; that he had applied for admission at the Port of Seattle, and was denied the same on the ground that he was not illegally entitled to be admitted therein. The petitioner set up his grounds that he was being deprived of his liberty without due process of Law, and without being given a fair hearing; and among other things, that he was not allowed to consult counsel, or was he advised of his right to have counsel; that he was further denied the right to have withness for and in his behalf, or was he advised of his right to have witnesses appear for and in his behalf; and that he was denied the right to face his witnesses; and further that he was the minor son of an American citizen, and being so, to deny him the right to enter, deprives him of his liberty without due process of Lawand in violation of the Constitution of the United States.

The evidence in the case shows that Wing Hin, the father of the detained alien, was born in San Francisco, in or about the year 1877. He later went to China and returned to the United States in July, 1896, by way of Richford, Vt. On July 8th of the same year, he was detained on a deportation proceeding, and a hearing was had before Felix W. McGettrick, United States Commissioner for the District of Vermont. The Complaint was signed by John H. Senter, United States Attorney for said District, and upon a hearing on July 9th, 1906, he was discharged, and a certificate issued which will be found in the record of this case, in Exhibit No. 29142, said certificate being the judicial finding of said United States Commissioner that Wing Hin, the -1-
father of your petitioner Chin Quock Wah, was a citizen of the United States. And I respectfully ask your Honor to examine the Seattle record 29142 covering the admission of Chin Wing Hin, or Wing Hin, as the record shows he is sometimes called, the father of Chin Quock Wah, when he arrived in Seattle from a visit to China, on January 20th, 1914, at which time the question of the right of the father of your petitioner to enter was examined, and his status them made, which said record was made a part of this present case, and should be in the files and examined by your Honor in arriving at a proper decision of this case. In that record, as well as in the record here, your Honor can easily discern the identity of your petitioner as being the minor son of Chin Wing Hin, his father, who is a merchant in Boston and a citizen of the United States.

Taking up the questions in order, I will first present to your Honor the question of not being advised of the right to have counsel or of facing his witnesses. If your Honor will examine the record in this case, you will find that after a preliminary hearing and a first hearing had occurred, upon receiving advice from one of the Inspectors in Boston, the local Inspectors arbitrarily examined your petitioner at the Seattle Immigration Station, and then and there without giving him the right to have counsel, proceeded to obtain from him such information as they saw fit in order that they might entangle him in making contrary statements. This, in my opinion, is entirely in violation of Law and of the rights of a detained as set down by custom procedure, or on any construction of a fair hearing. I will grant that the Law provides that, preliminary to admission at the preliminary hearing touching the right of the alleged alien to admission, there need be no counsel; but after asking the detained if he wished counsel, to then want a further hearing and not grant him that priviledge, then that is not a fair hearing, in my humble opinion.

Touching the question of the identity of the son: It seems -2-
to me that there is no question that your petitioner is the son of Chin Wing Hin, and this Court is not going to lend itself to sanction any arbitrary finding that he is not, unless it be supported by evidence, which the record in this case does not show.

Therefore, we reach the question as to the legal effect of the McGettrick certificate granting the father of your petitioner the right to enter in 1896 as an American citizen; for the statutes granting the Secretary of Labor to reply only when there be evidence showing that it is legal and proper under the existing Law, and it would be arbitrarily considered and sanctioned by the Court in the case of th ex-parte Lam Pui, 217 Federal, page 462. In the same case, Mr. Justice Conner, in determining the legal effect of a certificate , though it be a different certificate than the one in question, calls for the same kind of conclusion, states "While this certificate may be overcome by proper evidence and may not have the effect of a judicial determination, yet being made in conformity to the treaty, and upon it the Chinaman having been duly admitted to a residence in this country, he can not be deported, unless there is some competent evidence which would overcome the legal effect of the certificate". So in this case, in relation to this McGettrick certificate, unless there is some competent evidence to show fraud or to overcome the legal effect of it, I earnestly content that it is res judicata. As to the identity and statutes of the father of this petitioner as an American citizen, Mr. Justice Conner in the same case quotes abundant authorities, some of which are as follows:
This ruling is abundantly sustained by the words of Mr. Justice Holmes in Chin Yow v. United States, 208 U. S. 8,28 Sup. Ct. 201, 58 L. Ed. 369, and other cases cited in the opinion.
In United States v. Redfern (D. C.) 210 Fed. 548, Foster, District Judge, says:

"Congress has, indeed, vested the immigration officers with enormous power, subject to no check save their own consciences; but in granting them discretion to arrest and deport any person charged with being an alien and unlawfully in the country, I cannot believe that it was ever intended that they could do so arbitrarily, and without some evidence upon which to base their decision".
In United States v. Quan Wah (D. C.) 214 Fed. 462, Chatfield, District Judge, Says:

"Nor can the fact that the burden of proof to show right to be in the United States is thrown upon the Chinaman necessitate his further showing that the action of the authorities who decided he had the right to enter was correct, unless the evidence shows that his entry was fraudently obtained. - - - The decision of his right to enter was presumptively correct, and unless the United States shows persuasively to the contrary, the mere certificate of admission is sufficient"

In United States v. Williams, 200 Fed. 538 C. C. A. 632 (C. C. A., 2nd Circuit) Judge Noyes wrote the opinion for the court. Judges Cox and Ward, thinking that their views upon this point were not expressed clearly, concurring, said:

"The opinion does not, however, make entirely clear our views upon a single point. We think that some evidence must be presented to justify a judgment of deportation and that conclusions of law must have some facts upon which to rest. The immigrant may, in a sense, have a fair hearing, although the conclusions drawn by the executive officers be wholly unsupported by proof".

Text-writers and judges have undertaken to define the word "evidence", as applicable to judicial investigation, with more or less success. Probably no more satisfactory definition is found, for practical purposes, than that given by Mr. Edward Livingstone:
"Evidence is that which brings to the mind a just conviction of the truth or falsehood of any substantive proposition which is asserted or denied"

It is elementary that in judicial proceedings the question whether the record discloses any evidence is for the court. The weight to be given evidence is for the trier of the issue of fact. It is also elementary that mere suspicion, conjecture, speculation, is not evidence, neither can it be made the basis for finding a fact in the issue. The industry of counsel affords a number of illustrative expressions of courts. In People v. Van Zile, 143 N. Y. 372, 38 N. E. 381, Andrews, Chief Justice, says:
"Suspicion cannot give probative force to testimony which in itself is insufficient to establish or to justify an inference of a particular fact."
Judge Caldwell, in Boyd v. Glucklich, 116 Fed. 131, 53 C. C. A. 451, well says:
"The sea of suspicion has no shore, and the court that embarks upon it is without rudder or compass."

Having then, I think, established to your Honor's satisfaction, under the decisions of our Courts, the effect of said McGettrick certificate, unless fraud was shown which was not done in this case, I present to your Honor the case of Leung Jun v. the United States, 171 Fed. 413, where it was held that upon a hearing before the United States Commissioner, the petitioner, a Chinese person, presented a judgment of discharge by a United States Commissioner, and the only question presented was whether such judgment of discharge construed conclusive ajudicatum of the Chinaman's right to remain in -4-
the United States, and the entire Court held that it did, and ordered the petitioner discharged.

This decision was followed by Mr. Justice Morton of the United States District Court for the District of Massachusetts on January 19th, 1915, in the case of Lew Ah Jung. The evidence in this case was as follows: Jung, the petitioner, was arrested on deportation proceedings on the ground that he was in this country unlawfully. The evidence showed that he was born in San Francisco about the year 1884; that he went on a visit to China, and returned to the United States in 1897 by way of Richford, Vt. He was there arrested where hsi right to enter was questioned. His case was heard before Felix W. McGettrick, the United States Commissioner in Vermont, who, after his statutes had been fixed, and the certificate being in conformity with Law. I respectfully ask your Honor to examine this decision which you will find enclosed in an envelope in the files of this case, bearing the seal of the Massachusetts District Court. As before stated, this certificate showing the status of the father of your petitioner, is before your Honor being a part of the files and record, and is the same kind of a certificate as was in the case decided by Mr. Justice Morton.

After examining the entire record and the authorities herein cited, I feel certain that your Honor will hold that as a matter of Law that the son's status was fixed by his father's status, and that the son should be admitted to land, as being the son of an American citizen. For, as suggested by Mr. Justice Miller in the slaughter-house cases, 16 Wall. 36: "Another privilege of a citizen of the United States is to demand the care and protection of the Federal Government over his life, liberty and property when on the high seas, or within the jurisdiction of a Foreign Government." -5-
And why, then also, should not your Honor grant to this minor son of an American citizen, even though he be of a different color than most citizens, the strong arm of your Court to give unto him the equal rights and privileges which are accorded by the Constitution to all citizens; and instead of separating this young man from his father, allow him to be discharged and to proceed to join his father, who, as the record shows, has ample means,and intends,as expressed by him, to educate this young man and accord to him the benefits which every son has a right to expect from his father.
I feel certain that the construction of Law prepared by the learned counsel for the Government, does not apply in this case, and that the petitioner should be discharged forthwith.
Respectfully submitted,
